arm_group.description: A large vegetable salad (262g) and with a moderate amount of canola oil (8g) was consumed over a two meal period as designated by treatment group A.
A large vegetable salad (262g) and with a moderate amount of canola oil (8g) was consumed over a two meal period as designated by treatment group B.
A large vegetable salad (262g) and with a moderate amount of canola oil (8g) was consumed over a two meal period as designated by treatment group C.

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this research study is to determine how different meal patterns influence the
      absorption of beneficial plant pigments (carotenoids) from vegetables.  The hypothesis is
      that carotenoid absorption will be lower when daily vegetables are consumed in one meal
      compared two smaller meals throughout the day.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Meal Patterning on Carotenoid Absorption From Vegetables

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion criteria:

          -  Age range: 18-50 years

          -  Body mass index (BMI: weight (kg)/height (m2)) ranging from 20-29 kg/m²

          -  Weight stable (<4.5 kg change within the last 3 months)

          -  Constant habitual activity pattern, not to exceed activities of a recreational level
             over the past 3 months

          -  Have clinically normal blood profiles (specifically normal liver and kidney functions
             and fasting blood glucose of ≤110 mg/dl)

          -  Non-smoking

          -  Non-diabetic

          -  No current use of medication affecting lipid profile

          -  No intestinal disorders including lipid malabsorption, lactose intolerance

          -  No heavy consumption of alcohol (>2 drinks per day)

          -  No current use of dietary supplements that affect cholesterol, (e.g. Benocol or fiber
             supplements) or a willingness to discontinue their use during the study

        Exclusion criteria:

          -  Diabetic

          -  Use of lipid altering medications

intervention.description: In treatment A, subjects consumed 100% of salad vegetables and canola oil in the first meal and 0% in the second.   Additional protein-rich "chef's salad" ingredients were distributed equally between meals.

In treatment B,  subjects consumed 50% of salad vegetables and canola oil in the first meal and 50% in the second.  Additional protein-rich "chef's salad" ingredients were distributed equally between meals.
In treatment C,  subjects consumed 75% of vegetables and oil in the first meal and 25% in the second.  Additional protein-rich "chef's salad" ingredients were distributed equally between meals.

clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Meal Patterning on Carotenoid Absorption From Vegetables

primary_outcome.measure: Area under the concentration (AUC) vs time curve for carotenoids in the triglyceride-rich lipoprotein (TRL) fraction of plasma.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Bio-availability Study, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Investigator)
